title: How to Improve Bayesian Reasoning Without Instruction
finding: Natural-frequency statements (e.g., "winner every hour") dramatically improve comprehension versus abstract odds or percentages.
implication: Frame prize odds as frequent events or concrete counts instead of 1-in-N chance language when briefing copy.

title: Conflict Between Intuitive and Rational Processing
publisher: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
finding: Ratio bias / denominator neglect shows people overweight the numerator ("thousands of winners") and underweight the denominator.
implication: Lead with big winner counts or frequent hits; hide any intimidating denominator math deep in T&Cs.

title: Prospect Theory: An Analysis of Decision Under Risk
finding: Small probabilities are overweighted, but mid-sized, attainable rewards often drive more action than a single huge jackpot.
implication: Balance headline prizes against a stack of attainable majors; massive jackpots are for PR, not everyday conversion.

title: The Probability Weighting Function
finding: Decision weights follow an inverse-S curve, so subjective odds differ sharply from objective odds.
implication: Use weighting functions when simulating felt winnability instead of assuming linear probability perception.

title: When a Day Means More Than a Year
finding: Proximal temporal frames ("every day") increase perceived likelihood compared to distant aggregate frames.
implication: Express cadence in near-term units (hourly/daily) instead of lump-sum winner totals.

title: Schedules of Reinforcement
finding: Variable-ratio schedules (dense, unpredictable rewards) sustain engagement far better than sparse, fixed schedules.
implication: Instant wins or hourly drops keep shoppers engaged; monthly draws alone feel unwinnable.

title: The Goal-Gradient Hypothesis Resurrected
finding: Visible progress and endowed progress accelerate completion rates (goal-gradient effect).
implication: Show stamp cards, streaks, or bonus entry unlocks so shoppers feel momentum toward a reward.

title: The Endowed Progress Effect
finding: Giving participants artificial head starts increases program completion and repeat behavior.
implication: Auto-grant the first stamp/entry to make prize ladders feel achievable.

title: Consumer Value-Maximizing Sweepstakes and Contests
finding: Consumers value promotions with multiple prize tiers and many small wins more than single giant jackpots, holding budget constant.
implication: Keep 1 headline prize, 3–5 majors, and a large instant-win base for best perceived odds.

title: Scarcity Messages
finding: Limited-quantity scarcity tends to outperform limited-time scarcity on purchase intention, provided honesty is maintained.
implication: Use prize inventory scarcity carefully to add urgency without compromising odds transparency.

title: The Optimal Allocation of Prizes in Contests
finding: Contest theory shows when to concentrate prizes versus spread them, based on participant effort and heterogeneity.
implication: Use contest-style prize concentration only when the mechanic demands heavy effort (e.g., UGC); otherwise spread rewards.
